title: NSW land tax crackdown to hit developers, foreigners and farmers
text:
"Considering the government has said they expect to recoup approximately $100 million in unpaid land tax in the first year of this crackdown – clearly there is an anticipation that there are many instances of errors in self-reporting," Mr Paterson said.

Steven Paterson: Those potentially liable for land tax should act now.

"NSW is quite litigious and wins most of its land tax cases. The reason they win so often is that the burden of proof falls on the taxpayer – and without consistent documentation, this can be a difficult burden to meet."

Mr Paterson said the crackdown would hit property developers who did not subdivide farmland appropriately before commencing development.

"Take for example, if you have a five-hectare former primary production site and you commence development before subdividing the land, then you may no longer be eligible for an exemption on the entirety of that site," he said.

In the case of trusts, Mr Paterson said all discretionary trusts, unless worded otherwise, were generally considered to fall under the definition of a foreign person and thus liable for the land tax surcharge of 2 per cent.

"This may be a surprise to families and small companies, as well as individuals from other jurisdictions who have a different definition of foreign resident for the purposes of land tax," he said.

Tax expert Matthew Cridland, a partner at law firm K &L Gates, said incorrect claims of the primary production land tax exemption was an area where the firm typically saw taxpayer errors arise.

Advertisement

"The primary production use must be of a substantial commercial scale and undertaken with a profit-making intention," Mr Cridland said.

"In this scenario, hobby farms or running a few cattle to keep the grass down won’t suffice."

Revenue NSW has given taxpayers a three-month amnesty until January 31 to disclose landholdings and avoid penalty interest charges.

Mr Paterson advised those potentially liable for land tax to act now given much of the amnesty period covered the busy end of year and Christmas and New Year holidays.
description: Property developers who commence development before subdividing their land could be liable for land tax, warns Grant Thornton.
